properties.media:imagetext:
Chungking
Nov. 5, 1938
Personal
and
Confidential
Mr. H. M. Bixby
Pan American Airways
New York, N. Y.
Dear Bix:
Your long personal letter of Oct. 17th was received yesterday, coming up
on the plane from Hong Kong that morning• I an enclosing in
this envelope another
personal letter which I had written to you two days ago but am writing this now
to reply to some specific questions raised in your letter and also because I was
to get your lotter and I feel inspired to answer it.
With the
experience I have had
in the New York office and with what you
mentioned I can easily imagine the general
situation just now although no doubt I
do not do
the subject full justice.
I have my troubles but I will keep them and
you can have yours.
In a letter to Mr. Morgan written last night and going forward by this
mail I outlined our present general
situation particularly with respect to getting
into Hanoi, a
point mentioned in your letter.
I will only add that we are fully
alive to the
inherent risks connected with
flying
into Hongkong under the present
conditions and we are doing and have been doing all possible to complete the
necessary arrangements
fly into Hanoi.
I have personally discussed the matter
with DR. Kung,
T.V. Soong and the Minister of Communications.
I started on Aug• 24th
the day
Woods
Was
shot
down and have been following it up closely.
It would take the
weoght of several years off of me
to get into Hanoi
just now. I think we will but
I do not know when.
Referring to your comments
on CNAC being behind schedule in payments I
am glad to say that thás condition has greatly improved since you wrote your letter.
We have collected for the two cyclone engines, the DCIwo center
section, have
completed the payments on
the Commodores and have added about US$10,000.00
to
CNAC's fixed deposit making a total deposit of approximately US$20.000.00.
This
however I am afraid is about as far as I can go, except of course, getting the money
for spare parts orders when they arrive in Hongkong•
Regarding tka credits through
the American Export & Import Bank it would of course be very helpful but it seems
to me the detail for such an arrangement would be tremendous and there is really no
telling what obstacles
the Ministry would put in the way. They certainly would want
a percent for permitting the credit.
I know of a foreign group who had the reputation
and the capital who approached the
Ministry of Communications recently with an offer
to put twenty new three ton truck into
service out of Kunming, freight there is
piling up terribly,
if the Ministry would give them free rights during the war.
The
Minister demanded
twenty percent of the gross revenue as a tax for the Ministry and
stuck to it and the deal fell through. You would think that as great as their need for
transportation is now
a responsible trucking company would be offered a subsidy.
Also I do not think the situation out here is such that any one could offer credit to
CNAC or the Ministry. I think we shall just have to fight it out along the lines we
o 2201
